title: Nahum Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Nahum chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Nahum Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Nahum Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the author of the vision in Nahum 1:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Nahum the Elkoshite
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:1 states that the book is the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:2, how does the LORD respond to His adversaries?
options: He is jealous and takes vengeance
questions.correctAnswer: He is jealous and takes vengeance
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:2 says the LORD is jealous and revengeth on His adversaries.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1:3 says the LORD is quick to anger and easily forgives the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 states the LORD is slow to anger but will not acquit the wicked.

questions.question: What does the LORD do to the sea according to Nahum 1:4?
options: He rebukes it and makes it dry
He calms it and makes it peaceful
He parts it like the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: He rebukes it and makes it dry
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:4 says the LORD rebukes the sea and dries up all the rivers.

questions.question: Which places are mentioned as languishing in Nahum 1:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Bashan, Carmel, Lebanon
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:4 mentions Bashan, Carmel, and the flower of Lebanon languishing.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:5, what happens to the mountains and hills at God's presence?
options: Mountains grow taller and hills stand firm
Mountains are covered with snow and hills blossom
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains quake and hills melt
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:5 says the mountains quake and the hills melt at God's presence.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1:6 says that rocks are thrown down by the LORD's fury.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:6 clearly states that the LORD's fury throws down rocks.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1:7 describe the LORD to those who trust in Him?
options: A strong hold in the day of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: A strong hold in the day of trouble
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:7 describes the LORD as good and a strong hold for those who trust Him.

questions.question: What will happen to the enemies according to Nahum 1:8?
options: Darkness shall pursue them after a flood
They will be forgiven and restored
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness shall pursue them after a flood
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:8 says the LORD will make an utter end of the place with an overrunning flood and darkness will pursue the enemies.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:9, what will not rise up a second time?
questions.correctAnswer: Affliction
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:9 states affliction shall not rise up the second time.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Nahum 1:10: 'For while they be folden together as ______, and while they are drunken as drunkards...'
questions.correctAnswer: thorns
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:10 uses the phrase 'folden together as thorns' in describing the enemies.

questions.question: Who is described as 'a wicked counsellor' in Nahum 1:11?
questions.correctAnswer: One come out of thee
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:11 refers to 'one come out of thee' as a wicked counsellor imagining evil against the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1:12 promises that the LORD will afflict the people no more after previously afflicting them.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:12 states the LORD will afflict them no more after having afflicted them.

questions.question: What will the LORD do to the yoke and bonds according to Nahum 1:13?
options: Break the yoke and burst the bonds
Strengthen the yoke and tighten the bonds
questions.correctAnswer: Break the yoke and burst the bonds
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:13 promises the LORD will break the yoke and burst the bonds in sunder.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:14, what will happen to the graven and molten images?
options: They will be cut off from the house of the gods
questions.correctAnswer: They will be cut off from the house of the gods
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:14 states the LORD will cut off the graven and molten images from the house of the gods.

medium.title: Nahum Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Nahum Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Nahum 1, what biblical truth would you share about God's character in times of trouble?
options: God is slow to anger and a stronghold in the day of trouble
God is indifferent to the troubles of His people
God punishes without mercy and never forgives
God is distant and unapproachable in hardships
questions.correctAnswer: God is slow to anger and a stronghold in the day of trouble
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 shows God is slow to anger and great in power, while Nahum 1:7 states that the LORD is good and a stronghold in the day of trouble, knowing those who trust in Him.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1 teach us about trusting God when facing adversaries or enemies?
options: Trust that God will take vengeance and reserve wrath for His enemies
Trust in your own strength to overcome adversaries
Compromise with enemies to find peace
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will take vengeance and reserve wrath for His enemies
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:2 explains that the LORD takes vengeance on His adversaries and reserves wrath for His enemies, encouraging believers to trust His justice rather than relying solely on themselves.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with anger and impatience. According to Nahum 1, what should they remember about God's anger?
options: God is slow to anger and does not acquit the wicked
God immediately punishes at the slightest offense
God's anger is fleeting and unimportant
questions.correctAnswer: God is slow to anger and does not acquit the wicked
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 highlights that the LORD is slow to anger but great in power and will not acquit the wicked, reminding believers to be patient and trust God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1 teach about God's control over nature and circumstances that can encourage believers in spiritual discipline?
options: God commands the sea, dries rivers, and causes mountains to quake
Nature is uncontrollable and chaotic without God's involvement
God lets nature act independently of His will
Nature is unrelated to God's power
questions.correctAnswer: God commands the sea, dries rivers, and causes mountains to quake
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:4-5 describe God rebuking the sea, drying rivers, and causing mountains to quake, illustrating His sovereignty over all creation which encourages believers to trust and obey Him.

questions.question: A believer is facing severe trials and doubts if they can stand before God’s judgment. What truth from Nahum 1 encourages perseverance?
options: No one can stand before God’s indignation, but He is good to those who trust Him
Everyone will be crushed by God’s anger without exception
God’s judgment is arbitrary and unpredictable
Trials mean God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: No one can stand before God’s indignation, but He is good to those who trust Him
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:6 shows the fierceness of God’s anger while Nahum 1:7 reassures that the LORD is good and knows those who trust Him, encouraging believers to rely on God's goodness amid trials.

questions.question: Which biblical virtue is demonstrated by the promise in Nahum 1:13 about breaking yokes and bursting bonds?
options: God’s deliverance and freedom for His people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s deliverance and freedom for His people
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:13 promises that God will break the yoke and burst the bonds of His people, teaching believers about God’s power to deliver and restore freedom.

questions.question: Based on Nahum 1, how should believers respond to wicked counsel or evil plans against God?
options: Trust that God will cut down the wicked counsel and their plans
Support wicked plans for personal gain
Ignore the presence of evil counsel
Make plans to outwit the wicked counsel by their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will cut down the wicked counsel and their plans
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:11-12 speaks of a wicked counsellor who imagines evil against the LORD, but God declares that such plans will be cut down, encouraging believers to rely on God’s justice.

questions.question: A fellow believer is hesitant to share the Gospel fearing opposition. What encouragement from Nahum 1:15 can you share about proclaiming good tidings?
options: The feet of him who brings good tidings announce peace and deliverance
Sharing the Gospel is dangerous and should be avoided
Peace cannot be proclaimed until all opposition ceases
Good tidings are only for the righteous elite
questions.correctAnswer: The feet of him who brings good tidings announce peace and deliverance
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:15 celebrates the messenger who brings good tidings and proclaims peace, encouraging believers to boldly share the Gospel and trust in God’s protection.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1 instruct believers about God’s justice towards the wicked and the assurance of no repeated affliction?
options: God will make an utter end and affliction shall not rise up the second time
The wicked will always recover and afflict again
questions.correctAnswer: God will make an utter end and affliction shall not rise up the second time
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:9 states that the LORD will make an end and affliction will not rise a second time, assuring believers of God’s righteous final judgment against wickedness.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1, what practical lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from God’s power over the earth and its inhabitants?
options: All creation is subject to God’s presence, teaching humility and reverence
Humans should dominate nature without regard
Earth and its creatures are independent of God’s authority
Power over nature encourages pride and self-exaltation
questions.correctAnswer: All creation is subject to God’s presence, teaching humility and reverence
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:5 reveals that mountains quake and earth burns at God’s presence, reminding believers to live humbly and reverently before the sovereign Lord.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1 teaches that God’s fury is poured out like fire and can throw down rocks, showing the seriousness of His judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:6 describes God’s fury being poured out like fire and rocks being thrown down by Him, illustrating the seriousness and power of His judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1 encourages believers to perform their vows and keep their solemn feasts as part of faithful obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:15 calls on Judah to keep solemn feasts and perform vows, emphasizing the importance of obedience and worship in the life of faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Nahum 1:14 says the LORD will cut off the _______ and the molten image from the house of their gods because they are vile.
questions.correctAnswer: graven image
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:14 specifically mentions cutting off the graven image and molten image from the house of their gods as a judgment against idolatry.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1 guide believers in handling temptation and evil counsel they may face in daily life?
options: Trust God to cut down the wicked counsellor and resist temptation
Yield to temptation to avoid conflict
Ignore evil counsel and do nothing
Try to overcome temptation by their own strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to cut down the wicked counsellor and resist temptation
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:11-12 tells of a wicked counsellor imagining evil against the LORD and God's promise to cut them down, teaching believers to trust God’s power in resisting temptation.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1, how should believers view God’s wrath in relation to forgiveness and love for neighbors?
options: God’s wrath is reserved for enemies but He knows and protects those who trust Him
God’s wrath is indiscriminate and without mercy
God never shows wrath and always forgives without judgment
God’s wrath has no impact on relationships with others
questions.correctAnswer: God’s wrath is reserved for enemies but He knows and protects those who trust Him
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:2 and 1:7 show that while God reserves wrath for enemies, He is good and knows those who trust in Him, encouraging believers to love others while trusting God’s justice.

hard.title: Nahum Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Nahum Chapter 1.

questions.question: What characteristic of God is emphasized at the beginning of Nahum 1:2, highlighting His protective and jealous nature?
questions.correctAnswer: God is jealous
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:2 explicitly states, 'God is jealous,' emphasizing His zeal to defend His honor and take vengeance on adversaries.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:3, how does the LORD demonstrate His power over nature?
options: By controlling the whirlwind and the storm
questions.correctAnswer: By controlling the whirlwind and the storm
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 describes the LORD's power as shown in the whirlwind and storm, indicating His sovereignty over chaotic natural forces.

questions.question: In Nahum 1:4, which geographical regions are described as 'languishing' due to God's rebuke of the sea and drying up of rivers?
questions.correctAnswer: Bashan, Carmel, and Lebanon
questions.explanation: The verse names Bashan, Carmel, and Lebanon as regions affected by God's judgment on waters, symbolizing widespread desolation.

questions.question: Nahum 1:5 uses vivid imagery to describe the earth's reaction to God's presence. Which of the following best captures that imagery?
options: Mountains quake, hills melt, and earth burns
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains quake, hills melt, and earth burns
questions.explanation: Verse 5 describes mountains quaking, hills melting, and the earth burning at God's presence, signifying His overwhelming power.

questions.question: Who, according to Nahum 1:6, can stand before God's indignation and anger?
questions.correctAnswer: No one
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:6 rhetorically asks who can stand before God's fury, implying that no one can withstand His anger.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1:7 describes the LORD as indifferent to those who trust in Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:7 states that the LORD is a stronghold for those who trust in Him and knows them, indicating care and protection.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Nahum 1:8 to describe how God will destroy the enemies of Nineveh?
questions.correctAnswer: An overrunning flood
questions.explanation: Verse 8 uses the metaphor of an overrunning flood to depict the complete destruction God will bring upon Nineveh's enemies.

questions.question: In Nahum 1:9, what assurance does God give about the affliction He will bring upon His enemies?
options: Affliction shall not rise up the second time
questions.correctAnswer: Affliction shall not rise up the second time
questions.explanation: The verse assures that God's judgment is decisive and final, with affliction not repeating itself.

questions.question: Nahum 1:10 compares the enemies to which of the following, emphasizing their imminent destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: Stubble fully dry
questions.explanation: Enemies are likened to dry stubble, easily consumed by fire, symbolizing their vulnerability and destruction.

questions.question: Who is the 'wicked counsellor' mentioned in Nahum 1:11, and what is his significance in the context of the chapter?
options: A deceptive advisor who imagines evil against the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: A deceptive advisor who imagines evil against the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 11 identifies one from Nineveh who devises evil plans against God, highlighting the city's corrupt leadership.

questions.question: In Nahum 1:12, God declares He will no longer afflict His people after a period of suffering. What literary device is primarily used in this verse?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallelism with repeated phrasing 'Though they be quiet, and likewise many, yet thus shall they be cut down,' emphasizing the certainty of judgment.

questions.question: What promise of liberation is given in Nahum 1:13 regarding the yoke and bonds?
options: God will break the yoke and burst the bonds
God will strengthen the yoke and bind the bonds
God will ignore the yoke and bonds
God will hide the yoke and bonds
questions.correctAnswer: God will break the yoke and burst the bonds
questions.explanation: Verse 13 promises deliverance by breaking oppressive yokes and bonds, symbolizing freedom from captivity.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:14, what will God do to the graven and molten images in the house of gods?
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them off
questions.explanation: God commands the destruction of idolatrous images, signifying judgment against false gods and their worshipers.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'feet of him that bringeth good tidings' in Nahum 1:15, and how does this connect to New Testament imagery?
options: They symbolize the messenger of peace, paralleling the gospel 'feet' in Romans 10:15
They represent a warrior king, unrelated to New Testament imagery
They are a metaphor for destruction, contrasting New Testament hope
They refer to a prophet's journey with no New Testament parallel
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize the messenger of peace, paralleling the gospel 'feet' in Romans 10:15
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:15's 'feet of him that bringeth good tidings' echo the New Testament passage Romans 10:15, which speaks of the feet of those bringing the gospel of peace.

questions.question: True or False: Nahum 1 portrays God primarily as a patient and forgiving deity who overlooks wickedness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though God is slow to anger (v. 3), Nahum 1 reveals that He will not acquit the wicked and is furious in taking vengeance, emphasizing His justice.

theological.title: Nahum Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Nahum Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What attribute of God is primarily emphasized in Nahum 1:2 regarding His response to evil?
options: God is jealous and takes vengeance on His adversaries
God is indifferent and passive toward sin
God is primarily merciful without judgment
God is only a God of peace
questions.correctAnswer: God is jealous and takes vengeance on His adversaries
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:2 highlights God's jealousy and His active vengeance toward enemies, showing His holiness and justice. This aligns with Exodus 34:14, Deuteronomy 32:35, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 6:10, affirming God's righteous judgment across Scripture.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:3, which of the following best expresses God's patience and power?
options: The LORD is slow to anger and great in power
The LORD is quick to anger and weak in power
The LORD is indifferent and powerless
The LORD is always wrathful with no mercy
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is slow to anger and great in power
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 states God's slowness to anger combined with great power, affirming His longsuffering nature (Psalm 86:15, 2 Peter 3:9) along with His omnipotence (Jeremiah 32:17, Revelation 19:6).

questions.question: In Nahum 1:4, what natural elements does God control to demonstrate His sovereignty?
options: He rebukes the sea, dries rivers, and causes mountains to quake
He creates fire and lightning only
He controls only the sun and moon
He commands only animals and plants
questions.correctAnswer: He rebukes the sea, dries rivers, and causes mountains to quake
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:4–5 describes God's control over sea, rivers, mountains, and hills, demonstrating His sovereign rule over creation, consistent with Job 9:8, Psalm 104:7-8, and Jeremiah 10:12.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Nahum 1:6 ask about God's anger?
options: Who can stand before his indignation?
Who can forgive sins like the LORD?
Who can see God face to face?
questions.correctAnswer: Who can stand before his indignation?
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:6 asks who can endure God's fierce anger, emphasizing His overwhelming power and justice. This theme appears also in Isaiah 66:15, Hebrews 10:31, and Revelation 1:15.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:7, what is the LORD to those who trust in Him?
options: A stronghold in the day of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: A stronghold in the day of trouble
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:7 portrays God as a refuge and protector for those who trust Him, resonating with Psalm 46:1, Proverbs 18:10, Isaiah 26:4, and 2 Timothy 4:18.

questions.question: What is the fate of God's enemies as described in Nahum 1:8?
options: They will be overtaken by an overrunning flood and pursued by darkness
They will be forgiven and restored
They will be exalted among nations
questions.correctAnswer: They will be overtaken by an overrunning flood and pursued by darkness
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:8 uses imagery of floods and darkness pursuing enemies to depict God's decisive judgment, consistent with Exodus 15:12, Isaiah 59:9, Psalm 18:4, and Revelation 16:10.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1:9 describe the Lord's ability to deal with opposition?
options: He will make an utter end; affliction will not rise a second time
He will ignore the opposition indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: He will make an utter end; affliction will not rise a second time
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:9 assures that God's judgment is final and effective, preventing repeated affliction, paralleling Isaiah 10:27, Ezekiel 18:23, Hebrews 10:26, and Revelation 20:10.

questions.question: What metaphor does Nahum 1:10 use to describe the destruction of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Devoured as fully dry stubble
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:10 compares the wicked to dry stubble easily consumed by fire, illustrating their vulnerability to God's judgment. Similar metaphors appear in Isaiah 1:31, Jeremiah 5:14, Malachi 4:1, and Matthew 3:12.

questions.question: Who is described in Nahum 1:11 as coming out from Nineveh and imagining evil against the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked counsellor
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:11 identifies a 'wicked counsellor' who plots evil against God, highlighting human rebellion against divine authority, consistent with Isaiah 14:13-14, Psalm 2:1-2, Romans 1:30, and 2 Timothy 3:13.

questions.question: What promise does God give in Nahum 1:12 concerning His affliction on His people?
options: Though afflicted before, He will afflict them no more
He will increase their suffering continuously
He will punish them without end
questions.correctAnswer: Though afflicted before, He will afflict them no more
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:12 promises cessation of affliction, indicating God's mercy and restoration, as also seen in Isaiah 54:7, Jeremiah 31:3, Hosea 2:14, and Romans 8:1.

questions.question: What action does God declare He will take in Nahum 1:13 regarding the yoke and bonds on His people?
options: He will break the yoke and burst the bonds in sunder
He will strengthen the yoke and bonds
He will hand them over to their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He will break the yoke and burst the bonds in sunder
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:13 reveals God's deliverance by breaking the oppressive yoke and bonds, reflecting His redemptive power like in Isaiah 10:27, Psalm 107:14, Luke 4:18, and Galatians 5:1.

questions.question: According to Nahum 1:14, what will God do to the idols of the enemy?
options: Cut off the graven and molten images
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off the graven and molten images
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:14 declares God will destroy idols, demonstrating His opposition to idolatry, as affirmed in Exodus 20:4-5, Psalm 115:4-8, Isaiah 44:9-20, and 1 Corinthians 8:4-6.

questions.question: What message is proclaimed in Nahum 1:15 upon the mountains?
options: The feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace
A declaration of war and destruction
questions.correctAnswer: The feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:15 announces the arrival of a messenger bringing good news and peace, a messianic theme echoed in Isaiah 52:7, Romans 10:15, Luke 2:10, and Ephesians 6:15.

questions.question: What does Nahum 1:3 mean when it says 'the LORD hath his way in the whirlwind and in the storm'?
options: God sovereignly governs even chaotic and powerful natural forces
God is powerless in storms and whirlwinds
God only acts in calm and peaceful settings
God is angry with nature itself
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly governs even chaotic and powerful natural forces
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:3 uses natural imagery to show God's control over all creation, including chaotic forces, paralleling Psalm 18:10, Job 38:1-41, Isaiah 40:12-31, and Mark 4:39.

questions.question: How does Nahum 1:7 relate to the doctrine of God's providence and care for His people?
options: God knows and strengthens those who trust Him as a stronghold in trouble
God is indifferent to human trust and suffering
God punishes those who trust Him
God abandons His people in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God knows and strengthens those who trust Him as a stronghold in trouble
questions.explanation: Nahum 1:7 affirms God's intimate knowledge and protection of trusting believers, supporting the biblical teaching on God's providence found in Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 41:10, Matthew 6:25-34, and 1 Peter 5:7.
